SDG_GOAL: 8. Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
SDG_TARGET: 8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms
SDG_INDICATOR: 8.7.1: Proportion and number of children aged 5-17 years engaged in child labour, by sex and age
STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Proportion of children aged 5-17 years (MICS) (or 10-14 years for ICDS) engaged in economic activity and household chores at or above the age specific threshold.

Concepts

An economic activity is defined as paid or unpaid work for someone who is not a member of the household, work for a family farm or business. .

A child that performed economic activities during the last week for more than the age-specific number of hours is classified as in child labour: (i). age 5-11: 1 hour or more; (ii). age 12-14: 14 hours or more; (iii). age 15-17: 43 hours or more.

Domestic work is defined as household chores such as cooking, cleaning or caring for children, as well as collecting firewood or fetching water.

A child that performed household chores during the last week for more than the age-specific number of hours is classified as in child labour. (i). age 5-11 and age 12-14: 21 hours or more; (ii). age 15-17: No limit to number of hour.

ICDS looks only at economic activity.
SOURCE_TYPE:
Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS):

The Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS) (2017) is a household based survey, which is conducted five years after a decennial census. It covers the whole country (all the ten provinces).

The aim of the survey is to gather information on population size and structure, population Distribution, migration, household characteristics, education, activity and labour force as well as mortality and orphanhood.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS):

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
COLL_METHOD:
ICDS

MICS

Sample design

The sample design for the 2017 ICDS is two stages, with Enumeration Areas (EAs) as the first stage and households as the second stage sampling units. In total, 400 EAs were selected with probability proportional to size (PPS), the measure of size being the number of households enumerated in the 2012 population census. The 2017 ICDS sample was stratified by province and urban/rural.

Sample design

Sample size

A representative probability sample of 11,200 private households was selected for 2017 ICDS. The ICDS was designed to produce estimates at national and provincial levels as well as for rural and urban areas.

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

The principal instrument used to collect primary data was the structured questionnaire uploaded on tablet which was administered through face-to-face interviews.

The questionnaire asks whether every birth of a child in the household has been registered.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

The child labour module was administered for one randomly selected child age 5-17 years in each household and includes questions on the type of work a child does and the number of hours he or she is engaged in it. Data are collected on both economic activities (paid or unpaid work for someone who is not a member of the household, work for a family farm or business) and domestic work (household chores such as cooking, cleaning or caring for children, as well as collecting firewood or fetching water).

Type of interview

Face to face Interviews were conducted with household heads. For the first time, the Zimbabwe ICDS used Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI) using mobiles devices

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place on 18-22 August 2017.

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training of trainers was conducted 3-4 August 2017. Training of field staff for the main survey was conducted from 7-11 August 2017.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

The response rate was 92.2 %.

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under age 5 and children age 5-17 years, respectively.

RATIONALE: Children around the world are routinely engaged in paid and unpaid forms of work that are not harmful to them. However, they are classified as child labourers when they are either too young to work or are involved in hazardous activities that may compromise their physical, mental, social or educational development.
DATA_COMP: Number of children in child labour divided by the total number of children in the population multiplied by 100.
DATA_VALIDATION:
ICDS: Steps undertaken to achieve this included field questionnaire editing, pre-programmed data entry template with in-built skipping and validation checks.

Data was merged into one data set by system developers who then analyzed and produced required tables using CSPro and SAS.

MICS: During data collection, the field supervisor is responsible for reviewing paper questionnaires for completeness and consistency before entering data into a tablet equipped with a data entry programme.

After the completion of data entry, data is cleaned by conducting internal tests for outlier answers and comprehensive audit rules. SPSS Version 24 was used to analyse data and Model syntax and tabulation plan developed by UNICEF were customized and used for this purpose.
DOC_METHOD: Global metadata prepared by custodian agencies are available for the indicator.
QUALITY_MGMNT: ZIMSTAT follows the recommendations of the UN Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, the African Charter on Statistics and UN National Quality Assurance Framework.
QUALITY_ASSURE: Data were received at the ZIMSTAT head office via the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) integrated into the management application on the supervisor’s tablets. Whenever logistically possible, synchronization was daily. The central office system developers installed application updates to field staff manually.
COVERAGE:
ICDS: The survey is conducted every tenth year. The first post-independence survey was in 1987, the second in 1997 and the third in 2007.

Data is disaggregated by sex.

MICS: The indicator is available since 2014. The survey is conducted every 5 years.

The indicator is available by sex, urban/rural, province, age, school attendance, mother’s education, child’s functional difficulties, mother’s functional difficulties, religion of household head and wealth index quintile.
COMPARABILITY: MICS and ICDS provide data for different age groups. Also, MICS includes both economic activity and household chores, while ICDS only includes economic activity.
